question: -- so they get there and they ask the guy real nice for some kind of i.d., and he gets agitated, starts screaming about viruses. Totally irrational, totally disoriented, doesn't know where he is, what day it is, alla that stuff. All they got was his name. They figure he's stoned out of his mind, it's some kinda psychotic episode, so they're gonna bring him...
answer: He's been tested for drugs?

question: Negative for drugs. But he took on five cops like he was dusted to the eyeballs. No drugs. You believe that?
answer: You have him in restraints.

question: Were you listening? We got two officers in the hospital. Yeah, he's in restraints, plus the medic gave him enough stellazine to kill a horse. Look at him! Still on his feet.
answer: That would explain the bruises, I guess. The struggle.

question: You want to go in? Examine him?
answer: Yes, please. You said he gave a name...

question: James Cole. That's everything we got. None of the James Coles on the computer match him. No license, no prints, no warrants. Nothing. You want me to go in with you?
answer: No, thank you.

question: I'll be right here...just in case.
answer: Mr. Cole? My name is Doctor Railly. I'm a psychiatrist. I work for the County -- I don't work for the police. My only concern is your well being -- do you understand that?

question: Mr. Cole? My name is Doctor Railly. I'm a psychiatrist. I work for the County -- I don't work for the police. My only concern is your well being -- do you understand that?
answer: I need to go now.

question: I'm going to be completely honest. I'm not going to lie to you. I can't make the police let you go...but I do want to help you. And I want you to trust me. Can you do that, James? May I call you "James"?
answer: "James"! Nobody ever calls me that.

question: Have you been a patient at County? Have I seen you someplace?
answer: No, not possible. Listen, I have to get out of here. I'm supposed to be getting information.

question: What kind of information?
answer: It won't help you. You can't do anything about it. You can't change anything.

question: Change what?
answer: I need to go.

question: Do you know why you're here, James.
answer: Because I'm a good observer. Because I have a tough mind.

question: I see. You don't remember assaulting a police officer...several officers?
answer: They wanted identification. I don't have any identification. I wasn't trying to hurt them.

question: You don't have a driver's license, James? Or a Social Security card?
answer: No.

question: Why not? Most people have some ID.
answer: You wouldn't understand.

question: You've been in an institution, haven't you, James? A hospital?
answer: I have to go.

question: A jail? Prison?
answer: Underground.

question: Hiding?
answer: I love this air. This is wonderful air.

question: What's wonderful about the air, James?
answer: It's so clean. No germs.

question: You're afraid of germs?
answer: I have to go.

question: Why do you think there aren't any germs in the air, James?
answer: This is April, right?

question: July.
answer: July?!

question: Do you know what year it is?
answer: What year is it?

question: What year do you think it is?
You think it's July of 1995? That's the future, James. Do you think you're living in the future?
answer: No, 1995 is the past.

question: 1995 is the future, James. This is 1989.
answer: Where are you taking me? South of France?! I don't want to go to the South of France. I want to make a telephone call.

question: Where are you taking me? South of France?! I don't want to go to the South of France. I want to make a telephone call.
answer: Lemme see your head, Jimbo, see if you got any creepy crawlies.

question: I need to make a telephone call.
answer: Gotta work that out with a doctor, Jimbo. Can't make no calls 'til the doctor says.

question: It's very important.
answer: What chew gotta do, Jimbo, is take it easy, relax into things. We all gonna get along fine if you just relax. Jeffrey. Yo! Jeffrey. This here is James. Whyncha show James around? Tell him the TV rules, show him the games an' stuff, okay?

question: This is a place for crazy people! I'm not crazy! Well, you've got some real nuts in here! Listen to me, all of you -- I have to tell you something that's going to be difficult for you to understand, but...
answer: Mr. Cole -- last night you told Dr. Railly you thought it was... 1995. ... How about right now? Do you know what year it is right now?

question: 1989. Look, I'm not confused. There's been a mistake, I've been sent to the wrong place. Hey, I'm not going to hurt anybody. Do any of you know anything about the Army of the Twelve Monkeys? They paint this, stencil it, on buildings, all over the place. Right. I guess you wouldn't, this is 1989, they're probably not active yet. That makes sense! Okay. Listen to me, three billion people died in 1995. Three billion, got that? Almost the whole population. Of the world! Only about one percent survived. Save you? How can I save you? It already happened! I can't save you. I'm simply trying to get some information for people in the present so that someday... You don't believe me. You think I'm crazy. But I'm not crazy. I'm a convict, sure, I have a quick temper, but I'm as sane as anyone in this room. I...
answer: Does this bother you, Mr. Cole?

question: No! Look, I don't belong here! What I need to do is make a telephone call to straighten everything out.
answer: Who would you call, Mr. Cole, who would straighten everything out?

question: Scientists. I'm supposed to report in to them. They'll want to know they sent me to the wrong time.
answer: So you could talk to these scientists and they do what? Send you to the future?

question: No, no. I can't talk to them. It's called, "voice mail". I'm supposed to leave messages. They monitor it from the present. No, no. This is the past. This has already happened. Listen... No, 1995 is the past, too. Look...
answer: These scientists, Mr. Cole? Are they doctors like ourselves?

question: No! I mean yes, but... Look, I've been given a lot of drugs but I'm still perfectly lucid. You have to let me use the phone. One call!
answer: It wasn't who you expected?

question: It was some lady. She didn't know anything.
answer: Perhaps it was a wrong number...

question: No. That's the reason they chose me -- I remember things.
answer: James, where did you grow up? Was it around here? Around Baltimore?

question: What?
answer: I have the...strangest feeling I've met you before...a long time ago, perhaps. Were you ever...?

question: Wait! This is only 1989! I'm supposed to be leaving messages in 1995. It's not the right number yet. That's the problem. Damn! How can I contact them?
answer: James, take these. Please -- I helped you like I said I would. Now I want you to trust me.

question: You think you can remove the grill but you can't. It's welded. See? I toldja. And all the doors are locked, too. They're protecting the people on the outside from us. But the people outside are as crazy as us. You know what "crazy" is? "crazy" is "majority rules". Take germs for example.
answer: Germs?!

question: In the 18th century there was no such thing! Nobody'd ever imagined such a thing -- no sane person anyway. Along comes this doctor...Semmelweiss, I think. He tries to convince people... other doctors mostly...that there are these teeny tiny invisible "bad things" called germs that get into your body and make you...sick! He's trying to get doctors to wash their hands. What is this guy...crazy? Teeny tiny invisible whaddayou call 'em?..."germs"! "What about the germs?" I say. He goes, "I don't believe in germs. Germs are just a plot they made up so they can sell you disinfectants and soap!" Now, he's crazy, right? Hey, you believe in germs, don't you?
answer: I'm not crazy.

question: Of course not, I never thought you were. You want to escape, right? That's very sane. I can help you. You want me to, don't you? Get you out?
answer: If you know how to escape, why don't you...?

question: Why don't I escape, that's what you were going to ask me, right? 'Cause I'd be crazy to escape! I'm all taken care of, see? I've sent out word.
answer: What's that mean?

question: I've managed to contact certain underlings, evil spirits, secretaries of secretaries, and assorted minions, who will contact my father. When he learns I'm in this kind of place, he'll have them transfer me to one of those classy joints where they treat you...properly. LIKE A GUEST! LIKE A PERSON! SHEETS! TOWELS! LIKE A BIG HOTEL WITH GREAT DRUGS Sorry. Really sorry. Got a little agitated. The thought of escaping crossed my mind and suddenly...suddenly I felt LIKE BENDING THE FUCKING BARS BACK, RIPPING OFF THE GODDAMN WINDOW FRAMES AND...EATING THEM, YES, EATING THEM, AND LEAPING, LEAPING... You dumb assholes! I'm a mental patient! I'm supposed to act out. Wait til you morons find out who I am. My father's gonna be really upset. AND WHEN MY FATHER GETS UPSET, THE GROUND SHAKES! MY FATHER IS GOD! I WORSHIP MY FATHER.
answer: They hurt you!

question: Not as bad as what they're doing to kitty.
answer: Look at those assholes, they're asking for it! Maybe people deserved to be wiped out!

question: Wiping cut the human race! That's a great idea! But it's more of a long term thing -- right now we have to focus on more immediate goals. I didn't say a word about "you know what".
answer: What are you talking about???

question: You know -- your plan. What're you writing? You a reporter?
answer: It's private.

question: Get it? Monk - Key. Monk! Key!
Wooooo, they really dosed you, bro. Major load! Listen up -- try and get it together. Focus! Focus! The plan! Remember? I did my part.
answer: What...???

question: I have to do this, James. You're very confused.
answer: Don't be defensive, Kathryn, this isn't an inquisition.

question: I didn't think I was being defensive. I was just...
answer: He should have been in restraints. It was bad judgment on your part, plain and simple. why not just cop to it?

question: Okay, it was bad judgment. But I have the strangest feeling about him -- I've seen him somewhere and...
answer: Two policemen were already in the hospital and now we have an orderly with a broken arm and a Security Officer with a fractured skull.

question: I said it was bad judgment! What else do you want me to say?
answer: You see what I mean? You're being defensive. Isn't she being defensive, Bob?

question: You see what I mean? You're being defensive. Isn't she being defensive, Bob?
answer: Uh, Dr. Fletcher -- we got another... situation.

question: He was in full restraints? And the door was locked?
answer: Yes, sir. Did it myself.

question: You're leaving? I'll be there in twenty minutes. You can have my purse. I have a lot of cash and credit... Here! You can have the keys. You can... Where... where are we going' But that's... that's more than 200 miles! If you make me go with you, it's kidnapping. That's a serious crime. If you let me go, you could just take the car and... Cole! James Cole! You escaped from a locked room six years ago.
answer: 1989. Six years for you. There's the sign! Right here!

question: I can't believe this is a coincidence, Mr. Cole. Have you been...following me?
answer: You told me you'd help me. I know this isn't what you meant, but...I was desperate... no money...bum leg... sleeping on the streets. I probably smell bad. Sorry about that. But then I saw your book in a store window with a notice about your lecture. I can read, remember?

question: Yes, I remember. Why do you want to go to Philadelphia?
answer: It's the next step. I checked out the Baltimore information, it was nothing. It's Philadelphia, that's where they are, the ones who killed everyone. Zs that a radio? Does it play music? I've never seen the ocean!

question: It's an advertisement, Mr. Cole. You do understand that, don't you? It's not really a special message to you.
answer: You used to call me "James".

question: You'd prefer that? ... James...you don't really have a gun, do you.
answer: Everybody's got a gun. In this city... Can you...can you make it louder? I love hearing twentieth century music! Hearing music and breathing air! "Never cry wolf!"

question: What?
answer: My father told me that. "Never cry wolf." Then people won't believe you if...something really happens.

question: "If something really happens"...like what, James?
answer: Something bad. Is that all the music? I don't want to hear this stuff...

question: Did something terrible happen to you when you were a child? Something so bad...?
answer: Ohhhh, that one! Can we hear that one? You were in my dream just now. Your hair was different, but I'm sure it was you.

question: We dream about what's important in our lives. And I seem to have become pretty important in yours. What was the dream about?
answer: About an airport...before everything happened. It's the same dream I always have -- the only one. I'm a little kid in it.

question: And I was in it? What did I do?
answer: You were very upset. You're always very upset in the dream, but I never knew it was you before.

question: It wasn't me before, James. It's become me now because of...what's happening. Please untie me.
answer: No, I think it was always you. It's very strange.

question: You're flushed. And you were moaning. I think you're running a fever. What are you doing?
answer: I'll be back in a minute.

question: No! Don't leave me here like this!
answer: My notes. Observations. Clues.

question: Clues? What kind of clues?
answer: A secret army. The Army of The Twelve Monkeys. I've told you about them. They spread the virus. That's why we have to get to Philadelphia. I have to find them -- it's my assignment.

question: What will you do...when you find this...secret army?
answer: I just have to locate the virus in its original form before it mutates. So scientists can come back and study it and find a cure. So that those of us who survived can go back to the surface of the earth. You won't think I'm crazy next month. People are going to start dying. At first the papers will say it's some weird fever, some virus. Then they'll begin to catch on. They'll get it. I thought it was about us. I thought maybe they'd found us and arrested me or something. Just a joke.

question: Does that disturb you, James? Thinking about that little boy in the well?
answer: When I was a kid I identified with that kid, down there alone in that pipe...a hundred feet down -- doesn't know if they're going to save him.

question: What do you mean -- when you were a kid?
answer: Nevermind. It's not real -- it's a hoax. A prank. He's hiding in a barn. Hey, turn left here. Left! Where I come from we think of this as Eden. If we could just see the sun, eat sun-grown food. Eden! Look at them! They donut know what they have. They don't see the sky. They don't feel the air! The Twelve Monkeys!!! They're here. Somewhere. Come on! Look, I'm warning you. You do anything, I'm going to go crazy -- hurt people!

question: They're keeping an eye on me.
answer: Who's keeping an eye on you?

question: The man...with the voice. I recognized him. He's from the present. He...
answer: James, no -- we shouldn't be here! James! We have to go back. Those men...

question: Please! Please don't hurt me! Are you hurt?
answer: Uh, no. Yes. I mean, just some scrapes... Is he...alive?

question: Come an. We're running out of time. You can't help him.
answer: Oh, Jesus, James! You killed him!

question: I did him a favor. Now come on.
answer: You didn't have a gun before, did you?

question: What's this?
answer: If those young men don't get loose, they could die in that basement.

question: All I see are dead people. Everywhere. What's three more?
answer: You know Dr. Mason's son, Jeffrey Mason, don't you, James? You met him in the County Hospital six years ago.

question: The guy was a total fruitcake.
answer: And he told you then his father was a famous virologist.

question: No -- he said his father was "God"!
answer: This can't go on, James. You're not well. You're burning with fever.

question: We need gas.
answer: I thought you didn't know how to drive.

question: I said I was too young to drive. I didn't say I was stupid.
answer: What's the matter with your leg?

question: I got shot. Look -- there's a gas station up ahead.
answer: Shot! Who shot you?

question: It was some kind of...war. Never mind, you wouldn't believe me. Turn off here. You were going to run out off gas on purpose, weren't you?
answer: No. I want you to turn yourself in, James -- It'll go much better for you if you do -- but I'm not going to trick you.

question: That has your name on it. Give him cash. Where are you going?
answer: You can come with me. I have to get some things. Scissors, bandages, some alcohol or whiskey. ... I have to look at your leg, James. I'm a doctor. You shouldn't put your weight on it. You need stitches and antibiotics. Lucky for you it was near the surface.

question: I love seeing the sun.
answer: Wait -- let me help you.

question: You smell so good.
answer: You have to give yourself up, you know.

question: This is ridiculous. My father is making a major address. Never saw him before in my life. Go ahead and shoot him or torture him or whatever it is you do.
answer: You do know me. You helped me once.

question: That would be totally out of character. Helping people is against my principles. See, he definitely doesn't know me. Now, I'm going to go back and listen to my father's very eloquent discourse on the perils of science WHILE YOU TORTURE THIS
answer: I'm here about some monkeys.

question: Excuse me -- what did you say?
answer: Monkeys. Twelve of them.

question: Arnold...Arnold. My God, Arnie, what's happened to you? You look like shit Of course I know him. What do you think -- I act like this to strangers? Listen -- you fellas are terrific. I thought you were pulling a number on me. What a terrible thing if you'd thrown old Arnie out. I owe you guys the big apologia! Mea culpa, fellas. Christ, Arnie, it's black tie! I mean, I said, "drop by," but, like, this is Dad's big "do"...vips, senators, secret service, and...and everything. Arnold Pettibone. Old Arnie Pettibone. Used to be my best friend. Still is. What've you lost, Arnie -- forty pounds? No wonder I didn't know you. You hungry? Lots of dead cow, dead lamb, dead pig. Real killer feast we're putting on tonight. Hey, nice ta see ya. Lookin' good! Hi, there. Yes, it has been a long time. County Hospital, right? 1989. The "Immaculate Escape" -- am I right? Why, thank you -- you look wonderful, too.
answer: Listen to me -- I can't do anything about what you're going to do. I can't change anything. I can't stop you. I just want some information...

question: We need to talk. Come on. Upstairs. I am a new person! I'm completely adjusted. Witness the tux. It's Armani. Who chattered? Goines? Weller?
answer: I just need to have access to the pure virus, that's all! For the future!

question: Come on, follow me. You don't lock so good.
answer: I don't have time to go upstairs. The police are looking for me. I need to know where it is and exactly what it is.

question: I get it! This is your old plan, right?
answer: Plan? What are you talking about?

question: Remember? We were in the dayroom, watching TV, and you were all upset about the...desecration of the planet. And you said to me, "Wouldn't it be great if there was a germ or a virus that could wipe out mankind and leave the plants and animals just as they are?" You do remember that, don't you?
answer: Bulishit! You're fucking with my head!

question: And that's when I told you my father was this famous virologist and you said, "Hey, he could make a germ and we could steal it!"
answer: Listen, you dumb fuck! The thing mutates We live underground! The world belongs to the fucking dogs and cats. We're like moles or worms. All we want to do is study the original...

question: You're right! Absolutely right. Me's a nut case, totally deranged. Delusional! Paranoid. HIS PROCESSOR'S ALL FUCKED UP, HIS INFORMATION TRAY IS JAMMED. YOU KNOW WHAT IT IS, THE "ARMY OF THE TWELVE MONKEYS"? IT'S A COLLECTION OF
answer: LIGHTS! LIGHTS!

question: You bastard! You total bastard! I could have died in there. If something had happened to you I would have died.
answer: I...I...I'm really sorry.

question: What have you done? Did you...kill someone?
answer: No! I...don't think so. I stole a car and they chased me. I hit a tree.

question: See -- you can drive after all!
answer: Yeah, sort of, I guess. I...I'm sorry I locked you up. I thought...I thought... I think maybe I am crazy!

question: What made you think that?
answer: Jeffrey Mason said it was my idea about the virus. And suddenly, I wasn't sure. We talked when I was in the institution, and it was all...fuzzy. The drugs and stuff. You think maybe I'm the one who wiped out the human race? It was my idea?

question: Nobody is going to wipe out the human race. Not you or Jeffrey or anybody else. You've created something in your mind, James -- a substitute reality. In order to avoid something you don't want to face.
answer: I'm..."mentally divergent". I would love to believe that.

question: It can be dealt with, but only if you want to. I can help you.
answer: I need help all right. They're coming after me.

question: First, it's important that you surrender to them instead of them catching you running. Okay?
answer: It would be great if I'm crazy. If I'm wrong about everything...the world will be okay. I'll never have to live underground.

question: Give me the gun.
answer: The gun! ... I lost it

question: You're sure?
answer: No gun! Stars! Air! I can live here. Breathe!

question: I'm going to attract their attention, let them know where we are, okay? They'll tell you to put your hands on top of your head. Do what they tell you. You're going to get better, James -- I know it!
answer: I love this world!

question: He not only used the word "prank" -- he said the boy was hiding in a barn.
answer: He kidnapped you, Kathryn. You saw him murder someone. You knew there was a real possibility he would kill you, too. You were under tremendous emotional stress.

question: For God sakes, Owen, listen to me -- he knew about the boy in Fresno and he says three billion people are going to die!
answer: Kathryn, you know he can't possibly know that. You're a rational person. You're a trained psychiatrist. You know the difference between what's real and what's not.

question: Let's consider again our current information -- if the symptoms were first detected in Philadelphia on June 28, 1995, that makes us know that...?
answer: It was released in Philadelphia, probably on June 14, 1995.

question: And it appeared sequentially after that in...?
answer: San Francisco, New Orleans, Rio de Janeiro, Rome, Kinshasa, Karachi, Bangkok, then Peking.

question: Meaning...???
answer: That the virus was taken from Philadelphia to San Francisco, then to New Orleans, Rio de Janeiro, Rome, Kinshasa, Karachi, Bangkok, then Peking.

question: And your only goal is...???
answer: To find out where the virus is so a qualified scientist can travel back into the past and study the original virus.

question: So that...???
answer: Uh, so that a vaccine can be developed that will, uh, allow mankind to reclaim the surface of the earth.

question: I SAW YOU! I SAW SOMEONE MOVING. I KNOW YOU'RE IN THERE!
answer: That's what they do -- secret weird stuff!

question: You! I know you!
answer: Not just on them. Do 'em on people, too -- down at the shelters. Feed 'em chemicals 'n take pictures of 'em.

question: Have you seen James Cole? The man...?
answer: They're watchin' you. Takin' pictures.

question: Kathryn!
answer: James! James! That's a policeman. Pretend you don't know me. If he sees you...

question: No, I want to turn myself in. Where is he? Don't worry -- it's all okay now. I'm not crazy any more! I mean, I am crazy, mentally divergent, actually, but I know it now and I want you to help me. I want to get well...
answer: James -- put your hands down and listen to me. Things have changed! James, come on! We have to get out of here!

question: I've seen that...before.
answer: James, trust me. We're in terrible trouble. We have to run.

question: James! Come on.
answer: I don't understand what we're doing.

question: We're avoiding the police until I can....talk to you.
answer: You mean, treat me? Cure me? Kathryn, those words on the wall -- I've seen them before... I...I...dreamed them.

question: An hour?! Here's ninety eight. For the night. Deal? Okay...you were standing there looking at the moon...you were eating grass... then what?
answer: I thought I was in...prison again.

question: Just like that? You were in prison?
answer: No, not really. It's...it's in my mind. Like you said.

question: You disappeared! One minute you were there, the next minute you were gone. Did you run through the woods?
answer: I don't know -- I don't remember.

question: The boy in the well. How did you know that was just a hoax?
answer: It was? I didn't...know.

question: James, you said he was hiding in the barn...
answer: I think I saw a TV show like that when I was a kid. Where a boy...

question: IT WASN'T A TV SHOW! IT WAS REAL!
answer: Well, maybe that kid saw the same TV show and copied it. Listen, you were right, it's all in my head. I'm mentally ill, I imagine all that stuff. I know they're not real, I can trick them, make them do what I want. I just worked on them in my head and I got back here. I can get better. I can stay here.

question: What does this mean to you?
answer: ...I had a dream about...something like that.

question: You had a bullet from World War One in your leg, James! How did it get there?
answer: You said I had delusions -- that I created a world -- you said you could explain everything...

question: Well, I can't. ... I mean...I'm trying to. I can't believe that everything we do or say has already happened, that we can't change what's going to happen, that I'm one of the three billion people who are going to die...soon.
answer: I want to be here. In this time. With you. I want to become...become a whole person. I want this to be the present. I want the future to be unknown.

question: This is definitely real
answer: What're you -- some kind of tough guy? You wanna be a hero? You gonna try and mess with me? Come on... Now that's a smart boy. But you, honey, you think you can go 'round me and peddle your fancy ass in this part of town, you bet your life we got what I would call a major goddamn misunderstandin'.

question: JAMES -- DON'T!
answer: You...heard...her. Don't do it, man.

question: I...I...We need cash, James.
answer: You two are crazy. I got friends. You put me in a closet, they're gonna be really pissed.

question: James, no!
answer: I have friends, man -- if you cut me... What...the...fuck..are you doing???

question: Oh, my God, James. Did you kill him?
answer: Just...just in case. In case I'm not crazy... That's how they find us. By our teeth. I don't want them to find me. Ever. I don't want to go back.

question: Push it tight! Wait here. I'm going to try that phone number. Let's hope it's nothing! James! James! It's okay. We're insane! We're crazy! It's a Carpet Cleaning Company...
answer: A Carpet Cleaning Company?

question: No superiors! No scientists. No people from the future. It's just a Carpet Cleaning Company. They have voice mail -- you leave a message telling them when you want your carpet cleaned.
answer: You... you left them a message?

question: I couldn't resist. I was so relieved. Wait'll they hear this nutty woman telling them...they better watch out for the Army of the Twelve Monkeys...
answer: "The Army of the Twelve Monkeys -- they're the ones who are going to do it. I can't do anything more. The police are watching me."

question: You... you couldn't have heard me.
answer: They got your message, Kathryn. They played it for me. It was a bad recording...distorted. I didn't recognize your voice.

question: Let's do it! Okay, that's Stage One. In Stage Two, Monkey Four is over here... Ah, but cruelty is his specialty. Want the full effect?
answer: Jeffrey? I know it's you, Jeffrey. I recognize your voice. JEFFREY??? ... Very well. You're out of your mind, Jeffrey. I know all about your insane plan. That woman -- your psychiatrist -- she told me. I didn't believe her -- it seemed too crazy even for you. But, just in case, I took steps to make sure you couldn't do it. I took myself out of the loop! I don't have the code any more. I don't have access to the virus. So, go ahead -- torture me, but you can't extract anything of use to yourself.

question: What...virus?
answer: She knew about it, Jeffrey. She knew you were going to try this.

question: What virus are we talking about, Dad?
answer: You're insane, Jeffrey.

question: You "develop" viruses and you're calling me insane? Typical. What does this virus attack? Don't tell me, you sick fuck, it doesn't matter. Have I ever "developed" a virus? Do I put helpless animals in cages and measure their reactions to electrical stimuli? Do I inject radioactive substances into living creatures and examine their bowel movements? Wow! And I'm crazy!
answer: Please tell me, Jeffrey, what exactly are you going to do? I don't have to tell you I'm afraid.

question: Here, let me help you.
answer: I think I've seen this movie before. When I was a kid. It was on TV.

question: Shh -- don't talk. Hold still.
answer: I have seen it, but I don't remember this part. Funny, it's like what's happening to us, like the past. The movie never changes -- it can't change -- but everytime you see it, it seems to be different because you're different -- you notice different things.

question: If we can't change anything...because it's already happened, then we ought to at least smell the flowers.
answer: Flowers! What flowers?

question: It's an expression. Here...
answer: Why are we doing this?

question: So we can stick our heads out the window and feel the wind and listen to the music. So we can appreciate what we have while we have it. Forgive me, psychiatrists don't cry.
answer: But maybe I'm wrong. Maybe you're wrong. Maybe we're both crazy.

question: In a few weeks, it will have started or it won't. If there are still baseball games and traffic jams, armed robberies and boring TV shows -- we'll be so happy, we'll be glad to turn ourselves in to the police.
answer: Where can we hide for a few weeks?

question: You said you'd never seen the ocean...
answer: Kathryn?! You were in my dream just now. I didn't recognize you.

question: Well, you look pretty different, too.
answer: I mean in my dream -- I didn't realize it was you. Then...I woke up and I...I thought you were gone.

question: I remember you...like this. I feel I've known you before. I feel I've always known you. Nine thirty
answer: Might be tight.

question: Tight? My watch says 7:30.
answer: On your normal mornin', okay, plenty a time, but today, gotta take inta account your Army-of-the-Twelve-Monkeys factor.

question: What? What did you say?
answer: Twelve Monkeys, honey. Guess you folks didn't turn on your radio this morning. Bunch a weirdoes let all the animals outta the zoo last night. Then they locked up this big shot scientist in one of the cages. Scientist's own kid was one a the ones did it!

question: Maybe it's going to be okay.
answer: I know this place! ... This is my dream.

question: Airports all look the same. Maybe it's... James! Your moustache! It's slipping.
answer: It's not just my dream. I was actually here! I remember now. My parents brought me to meet my uncle. About a week or two before...before...before everybody started dying.

question: They may be looking for us, James. Use this. You can fix it in the Men's Room.
answer: I was here...as a kid. I think you were here, too. But you...looked just like you look now.

question: James, if we're identified, they're going to send us someplace...but not to Key West!
answer: Right! You're right. I have to fix this.

question: I'll get the tickets and meet you... in the Gift Shop. Judy Simmons. I have reservations for Key West.
answer: Listen, I don't know whether you're there or not. Maybe you just clean carpets. If you do, you're lucky -- you're gonna live a long, happy life. But if you other guys exist and you're picking this up -- forget about the Army of The Twelve Monkeys -- they didn't do it. It was a mistake' Someone else did it. The Army of The Twelve Monkeys are just dumb kids playing revolutionaries. It was someone else! I've done my job. I did what you wanted. Good luck. I'm not coming back!

question: It's...a long story.
answer: Leave me alone! I made a report. I didn't have to do that. This is the present. This is not the past. This is not the future. This is right now! I'm staying here! You got that? You can't stop me! Jo...Jose????

question: Leave me alone! I made a report. I didn't have to do that. This is the present. This is not the past. This is not the future. This is right now! I'm staying here! You got that? You can't stop me! Jo...Jose????
answer: Pulling out the tooth, man, that was nuts! Here, take this.

question: What? What for? Are you crazy?
answer: Me? Are you kiddin? You're the one! You were a hero, man. They gave you a pardon! And whadda you do? You come back and fuck with your teeth! Wow!

question: How did you find me?
answer: The phone call, man. The phone call.

question: The call I just made? Five minutes ago?
answer: Hey, five minutes ago, thirty years ago! Yes, that phone call. I been in training for this a couple a months now -- ever since I got back from that... "weird" war we were in. You remember that? Here, take it, man! You could still be a hero if you'd cooperate!

question: Coma on, Cole, don't be an asshole. Look, I got orders, man! You know what I'm sposed to do if you don't go along? I'm sposed to shoot the lady! You got that? They said, "If Cole don't obey this time, Garcia, you gotta shoot his girlfriend!" I got no choice, man. These are my orders. Just take it, okay?
answer: This part isn't about the virus, is it?

question: Hey, man...
answer: It's about obeying, about doing what you're told.

question: They gave you a pardon, man. Whatdaya want?
answer: Who am I supposed to shoot?

question: Maybe we can stop him. Maybe we can actually do something.
answer: Me? Oh, yes, of course. My samples. I have the appropriate papers.

question: Oh, God, we don't have time for this.
answer: Biological samples. I have the paperwork right here. Open it? Of course. Here! You see? Biological! Check the papers -- it's all proper. I have a permit. Well, yes, to be sure, it looks empty! But I assure you, it's not.

question: Please listen to me -- this is very urgent!
answer: You see! Also invisible to the naked eye. It doesn't even have an odor.
